title: 1990s Australian TV miniature
credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
brief_description: This gorgeous miniature TV model celebrates the evolving living rooms of Australians and beloved TV from the 1990s.

constellations_primary.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_primary.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

description: Skippy had stiff competition for the title of Australia’s most beloved (and fictional) marsupial when Blinky Bill debuted in 1993. Based on Dorothy Wall’s books, the animated series incorporated environmental messages into its storylines and saw film and video game spin-offs. The analysis of Australian politics got satirical with Frontline, as local TV began to stretch the possibilities of what it could do creatively. While Home & Away was finding mainstream success, teenage soap Heartbreak High premiered in 1994 and tackled heady subjects for the time including racism, homelessness, drug addiction and sexuality. Crucially, it also introduced the phrase “rack off” into the pop-cultural lexicon.
